qas.question: Why did McKerrow alter his previous method of criticism?

answers.text: deviate more widely than the earliest print from the author's original manuscript."

qas.question: How did McKerrow alter his approach to copy-text analysis?

answers.text: inserting into it, from the first edition which contains them, such corrections as appear to us to be derived from the author."

qas.question: What did McKerrow concede about his new copy-text method?

answers.text: we must accept all the alterations of that edition, saving any which seem obvious blunders or misprints

qas.question: What work was the first to see McKerrow use his new method?
What book did Shakespeare publish in 1939?

plausible_answers.text: if it contained authorial corrections – would "deviate more widely than the earliest print from the author's original manuscript

qas.question: McKerrow stayed firm in which opinion?
How many revisions did early editions have?

plausible_answers.text: saving any which seem obvious blunders or misprints

qas.question: McKerrow thinks we should only accept one revision for what reason?

context: By 1939, in his <a3_0><b4_0>Prolegomena<b4_0/> for the Oxford Shakespeare<a3_0/>, McKerrow had changed his mind about this approach, as he feared that a later edition – even <b5_0>if it contained authorial corrections – would "<a0_0>deviate more widely than the earliest print from the author's original manuscript<b5_0/>."<a0_0/> He therefore concluded that the correct procedure would be "produced by using the earliest "good" print as copy-text and <a1_0>inserting into it, from the first edition which contains them, such corrections as appear to us to be derived from the author."<a1_0/> But, fearing the arbitrary exercise of editorial judgment, McKerrow stated that, having concluded that a later edition had <b6_0>substantive<b6_0/> revisions attributable to the author, "<a2_0>we must accept all the alterations of that edition, <b7_0>saving any which seem obvious blunders or misprints<b7_0/><a2_0/>."
